transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human
notes: Wallinga-Teunis method implemented via the R0 package to estimate effective reproduction numbers for nosocomial, extra-nosocomial outbreaks and KGH hospital data, incorporating a proportion Q of human-to-human transmission and zoonotic imports, with stochastic resampling to assess uncertainty.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human
assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Latent period is same as incubation period;Other
notes: Deterministic ODE model (system 1) describing SEIR dynamics in humans and SI dynamics in rodents, fitted to cumulative case data from Nigeria (2018-2020) using nonlinear least squares in MATLAB.

Model 1 simulates a cohort of 20 animals across 20 age classes using an Excel matrix. Assumes vertical transmission 5% and horizontal transmission 95%, incidence 5% per 30 days for age <240 days and 5% per 60 days for older age, duration of viremia 90 days for all ages, maternal antibodies present in 20% of newborns with loss within 120 days. Parameters were empirically optimized to fit observed virus and antibody prevalence data.

Model 2 extends Model 1 by allowing chronic infections with long-term viremia (300-600 days) for newborns and acute infections with short viremia (~30 days) for older animals. Assumes vertical transmission 5% and horizontal transmission 95%, incidence 5% per 30 days for age <240 days and 5% per 60 days for older, maternal antibodies in 20% of newborns lost within 120 days. Parameters empirically calibrated to match observed seroprevalence and virus prevalence across age classes.

Deterministic SIR compartmental model (with births, deaths, waning immunity) used to derive steady-state seroprevalence-incidence relationship for Lassa virus spillover from rodents to humans; parameters fitted from literature and seroprevalence data; applied per 0.05-degree pixel across West Africa.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human
assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Latent period is same as incubation period
notes: Six-compartment deterministic ODE model (human SEIR + rodent SI) describing Lassa fever transmission in Nigeria. Model includes human-to-human, rodent-to-human, human-to-rodent, and rodent-to-rodent transmission routes. Parameters estimated by fitting cumulative case data (NCDC, 2020-2021) using nonlinear least squares in MATLAB. Sensitivity analysis performed; control simulations explored reductions in transmission probabilities, increased rodent mortality, and increased human recovery (treatment). Assumes homogeneous mixing and that the latent period equals the incubation period. Spillover from rodent reservoir explicitly modeled.

Stochastic individual-based model of Lassa virus transmission in Mastomys natalensis. Six compartments (S, E, I, R, M, C). Horizontal transmission rate depends on density with parameter q; vertical transmission included. Parameterized using 4-year field data (rodent density, seroprevalence, age). Used to simulate control strategies: annual density control, continuous density control, and rodent vaccination. Code provided in supplementary R script.

Simple Poisson spillover model (Eq 1) representing independent random zoonotic spillover events, without depletion of susceptibles or human-to-human transmission. Used as baseline comparison with ABM.
Poisson‑Gamma mixture (negative binomial) spillover model (random rate λ drawn from a gamma distribution). Captures over‑dispersion in spillover events. Used for comparison with ABM (Fig 2c,d).
Self‑correcting Poisson model (Eq 5‑8) incorporating depletion of susceptibles (S_H) after each spillover event. No human‑to‑human transmission. Compared to ABM in Fig 3a.

transmission_route: Vector/Animal to human;Human to human (direct contact)
notes: Poisson with feedback model (Eq 9) representing zoonotic spillover as immigration and human‑to‑human transmission as self‑exciting (branching) process. No depletion of susceptibles. Used to generate analytic predictions (Fig 3b).

transmission_route: Vector/Animal to human;Human to human (direct contact)
notes: Combined 'zoonotic spillover with human‑to‑human transmission and depletion of susceptibles' model (Eq 9 with Eq 6‑8). Captures both self‑exciting and self‑correcting dynamics. Compared to ABM in Fig 3c.

transmission_route: Vector/Animal to human;Human to human (direct contact)
notes: Poisson‑Gamma mixture with feedback (stochastic spillover rate drawn from a gamma distribution combined with human‑to‑human self‑exciting process). Referred to as 'Poisson‑Gamma‑Mixture with Feedback' in the article. Used for comparison with ABM.

transmission_route: Vector/Animal to human;Human to human (direct contact)
notes: Individual‑based simulation of N_H agents transitioning between Susceptible, Infected, Recovered, Dead. Simulates zoonotic spillover (probability proportional to Λ_R) and human‑to‑human transmission (probability proportional to Λ_H). Used to validate analytic models (Figs 2‑4).

transmission_route: Vector/Animal to human;Human to human (direct contact)
notes: Poisson with feedback model (Eq 12) applied to Lassa Fever KGH data assuming constant zoonotic exposure (ζ). Parameters ζ and κ estimated via MCMC in R. Includes depletion of susceptibles, human‑to‑human transmission, and stochasticity.

transmission_route: Vector/Animal to human;Human to human (direct contact)
assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Heterogenity in transmission rates - over time
notes: Poisson with feedback model (Eq 12) applied to Lassa Fever KGH data with temporally varying zoonotic exposure (piecewise linear/triangular trend). Parameters ζ(t) and κ estimated via MCMC in R. Captures time‑dependent heterogeneity in spillover rate.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human;Airborne or close contact;Unspecified
notes: Deterministic compartmental ODE model for Lassa fever incorporating human (S, E, I_A, I_S, R) and rodent (S, E, I) populations, plus environmental surface (V_S) and aerosol (V_A) virus compartments. Multiple transmission routes modelled: human-to-human direct contact, rodent-to-human, rodent-to-rodent, environment-to-human, aerosol-to-human, environment-to-rodent. Parameters estimated by calibration to outbreak data; sensitivity and uncertainty analyses performed.

assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Latent period is same as incubation period;Other
notes: Integer-order deterministic SV1V2EUIR compartmental model for Lassa fever, with compartments Susceptible, first-dose vaccinated, second-dose vaccinated, Exposed, Undetected infected, Infected, Recovered. Includes vaccination as intervention.

assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Latent period is same as incubation period;Other
notes: Fractional-order deterministic SV1V2EUIR model using Caputo fractional derivatives to capture memory effects; solved via Laplace Adomian Decomposition method. Includes vaccination interventions.

transmission_route: Vector/Animal to human;Human to human (direct contact)
notes: Seasonally forced vector-host ODE model with human SEAIR compartments and rodent SIR compartments, linking rat reservoir dynamics to human Lassa fever cases; fitted to weekly confirmed case data (2018-2020) using Approximate Bayesian Computation Sequential Monte Carlo.

transmission_route: Vector/Animal to human;Sexual;Airborne or close contact
notes: The model is a deterministic compartmental ODE system with seven compartments: susceptible male (S1), infected male (I1), susceptible female (S2), infected female (I2), dormant reservoir (R1), active reservoir (R2), and environmental virus (V). It includes transmission via active reservoir (vector/animal), sexual contact, and environmental contamination. The model was solved numerically using fourth-order Runge-Kutta and analytically using the differential transformation method (DTM). Sensitivity analysis was performed on the basic reproduction number R0. Parameters were taken from literature; no fitting to empirical data was performed.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human
notes: Deterministic 7-compartment ODE model for Lassa fever transmission between humans (SEIR) and rodents (SEI) with saturated incidence functions for both human-to-human (β1) and rodent-to-human (β2) transmission, includes treatment of infected humans (η) and rodent reservoir, analyzed via stability, sensitivity, and numerical simulations using Maple.

assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Heterogenity in transmission rates - between groups
notes: Age-structured SIR model for Lassa virus within Mastomys natalensis reservoir, includes vertical transmission, maternal antibody transfer, and migration between metapopulation patches. Used for parameter inference via ABC.

assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Heterogenity in transmission rates - between groups
notes: Same age-structured SIR reservoir model extended with a vaccination term representing vaccine-laced bait consumption by susceptible juvenile and adult rodents. Simulated vaccination campaigns to assess efficacy.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human
notes: Deterministic seven-compartment ODE model for Lassa fever with human (S_h, E_h, I_h, I_sh, R_h) and rodent (S_r, I_r) compartments, incorporating isolation of exposed and infected humans, treatment of isolated individuals, and animal-to-human spillover.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human
notes: A deterministic seven-compartment ODE model for Lassa fever including human susceptible, carrier, infected, treated, recovered and rodent susceptible and infected compartments. Incorporates human-to-human transmission via carriers and infected individuals, and rodent-to-human transmission. Treated class is isolated (non‑infectious). Infected rodents do not recover. The model is analyzed analytically and simulated using MATLAB ODE45; no empirical data fitting or code repository provided.

assumptions: Heterogenity in transmission rates - between groups;Heterogenity in transmission rates - over time
notes: Zero-inflated negative binomial GLMM used to estimate seasonal and spatially heterogeneous zoonotic spillover rates across administrative units for each pathogen.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct non-sexual contact);Vector/Animal to human
notes: Stochastic branching process model for human-to-human transmission following spillover events, using Poisson offspring for LASV and RVF and negative binomial offspring for MERS and NiV, incorporating reactive vaccination strategies (population-wide, HCW, ring).

Age-structured SIR model with constant rodent spillover (force of infection λ) and uniform antibody waning (seroreversion rate), fitted to age-specific IgG seroprevalence data via maximum likelihood estimation in R. Used to estimate force of infection, antibody persistence, and explore impact of reducing spillover on active infection prevalence.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human
notes: Base deterministic SEIR model for humans (S, E, I, R) and SI model for rodents (S, I) describing Lassa fever transmission via human-to-human contact and rodent-to-human spillover.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human
notes: Optimal control version of the SEIR-SEI Lassa fever model incorporating three control variables: hand washing (behaviour change), environmental cleaning (vector/animal control), and treatment of infected humans.
Baseline target cell limited model of Lassa virus infection with AST dynamics, no drug interventions.
Model A: ribavirin reduces viral transmission rate β by factor (1-γ).
Model B: ribavirin reduces viral production rate p (in addition to favipiravir effect) by factor (1-γ).
Model C: ribavirin reduces infected cell death rate δ_I by factor (1-γ), leading to reduced AST production.
Model D: ribavirin increases infected cell death rate δ_I (δ_I/(1-γ)), modeling enhanced immune-mediated cell loss.
Model C1: extension of Model C with separate ribavirin effects on infected cell death (γ1) and AST production (γ2).
Model C2: extension of Model C adding ribavirin effect on viral production rate p (γ2).
Model C3: extension of Model C adding ribavirin effect on viral transmission rate β (γ).

assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Heterogenity in transmission rates - between groups
notes: Deterministic age-structured SICR model (juvenile and adult compartments) for Mastomys natalensis incorporating seasonal birthing and a chronic infection class; used to compute time-average basic reproduction number and perform sensitivity analysis.
Deterministic serocatalytic SIR model using forward Euler with 4‑week timesteps, incorporating births, deaths and spillover risk to estimate LASV infection incidence at district level.

transmission_route: Vector/Animal to human;Human to human (direct contact)
notes: Stochastic branching process model simulating human-to-human LASV transmission following spillover events, using R0=0.063, incubation and infectious period distributions, run per district (183 districts) over 10-year horizon.

transmission_route: Vector/Animal to human;Human to human (direct contact)
notes: Stochastic branching process model for hypothetical Lassa‑X virus, assuming Ebola‑like transmissibility, seeded by a single spillover event, simulating outbreaks lasting ~2 years across West Africa.

transmission_route: Vector/Animal to human;Human to human (direct non-sexual contact)
notes: Deterministic ODE model with nine compartments (human S, E, mild I, severe I, isolated I, recovered; rodent S, E, I). Incorporates rodent-to-human transmission, human-to-human transmission, treatment of mild and severe cases, and isolation of infected individuals. Includes spillover from rodent reservoir. Parameters taken from literature or assumed; model not fitted to actual outbreak data.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human;Airborne or close contact
notes: Deterministic compartmental ODE model for Lassa fever with human (S, E, I_A, I_S, R), rodent (S, E, I), and environmental virus (V_S, V_A) compartments; incorporates multiple transmission routes including human-to-human direct contact, rodent-to-human, rodent-to-rodent, environment-to-human, aerosol-to-human, and environment-to-rodent; sensitivity analyses performed.

Deterministic compartmental model using catalytic and reverse catalytic equations to estimate the force of infection (FOI) from rodents to humans, incorporate seroreversion, and compute age‑specific infection attack rates across West African admin1 and admin2 units. Parameters are fitted to serology and case data; uncertainty captured via posterior draws.
Poisson process model for animal-to-human spillover events only (no human-to-human transmission), used to derive vulnerability measures.

transmission_route: Vector/Animal to human;Human to human (direct contact)
assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Heterogenity in transmission rates - between human and vector;Heterogenity in transmission rates - over time
notes: Self-exciting Hawkes (branching) process model for zoonotic spillover combined with human-to-human transmission, used to derive vulnerability for diseases with both animal and human transmission.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human;Airborne or close contact
assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Latent period is same as incubation period;Other
notes: Full SEIR-SEI model with environmental virus compartment (V), fitted to weekly Lassa fever case data from Nigeria (2019-2020) using MATLAB lsqcurvefit.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Airborne or close contact
assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Latent period is same as incubation period
notes: Rodent-free sub-model derived from full model by setting rodent compartments to zero; includes human SEIR compartments and environmental virus compartment.

assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Latent period is same as incubation period;Other
notes: Rodent-virus sub-system obtained by setting human compartments to zero; includes rodent SEI compartments, logistic growth with vertical transmission, and environmental virus compartment.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human
assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Latent period is same as incubation period
notes: Human-rodent sub-model derived by setting environmental virus compartment V to zero; includes human SEIR compartments and rodent SEI compartments with logistic growth.

assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Latent period is same as incubation period
notes: Human-to-human transmission model obtained by removing rodent and environmental compartments from full model; includes human SEIR compartments with asymptomatic and confirmed classes.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human
assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Latent period is same as incubation period;Other
notes: Extended model replaces rodent subsystem with competitor species dynamics to assess impact of competitor rodent introduction on LF dynamics; simulated using same parameters as full model.

Deterministic SEIR model with vital dynamics (birth rate δ, death rate λ) describing Lassa fever transmission in humans. No vaccination or vector compartments. Parameters taken from literature, not fitted to outbreak data.

Deterministic SEIRS model with vital dynamics, vaccination of newborns and non‑newborns, and temporary immunity (flow from R back to S). Includes birth and death rates, vaccination rate v, and loss of immunity rate α. Parameters sourced from literature, not fitted to data.

Age-structured deterministic PDE model with compartments S, I, M, R; constant force of spillover λ from animal reservoir; includes waning immunity (ω) and clinical disease progression; used for analytical calculations and steady-state solutions; parameterized using literature values for Lassa virus.

Stochastic simulation of the age-structured model using Gillespie algorithm with τ-leaping (1 day timestep) and discrete age classes; includes transitions between compartments S, I, M, R; allows for maximum lifespan of 150 years; parameter values from literature; used to explore transient dynamics and uncertainty in burden outcomes.
Deterministic ODE compartmental model of Lassa fever with human SIR compartments and rodent SI compartments, including treatment compliance and education parameters.
Explicit Euler finite difference discretization of the continuous Lassa fever ODE model.
Classical fourth‑order Runge–Kutta (RK4) scheme applied to the Lassa fever ODE model.
Non‑standard finite difference (NSFD) discretization preserving positivity and boundedness of the Lassa fever model.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human
assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Latent period is same as incubation period;Other
notes: Deterministic SEIR model for humans coupled with SEI model for rodent reservoir, incorporating human-to-human and rodent-to-human transmission, vaccination, treatment and diagnostic (early treatment) parameters; analysis of equilibria, basic reproduction number, and sensitivity analyses using state-level Lassa fever data from Nigeria.

transmission_route: Vector/Animal to human;Human to human (direct contact)
notes: Deterministic five-compartment model (SI for rats, SIR for humans) with vector (Mastomys rat) to human and human-to-human transmission; parameters taken from literature; model not fitted to data.

transmission_route: Vector/Animal to human;Human to human (direct contact)
notes: Caputo fractional-order deterministic five-compartment model (SI for rats, SIR for humans) incorporating memory effects via fractional derivative of order α (0<α≤1); parameters from literature; model not fitted to data.

transmission_route: Vector/Animal to human;Human to human (direct non-sexual contact)
notes: Deterministic compartmental ODE model for Lassa fever with human compartments (S, E, I, D, UD, R) and rodent compartments (S, E, I). Includes detected and undetected cases, pulse vaccination, and rodent-to-human spillover. Analyzed using next‑generation matrix for R0, local and global stability (Routh‑Hurwitz, Castillo‑Chavez). Numerical simulations performed in Mathematica.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human
notes: Deterministic ODE compartmental model describing Lassa fever transmission between humans and rodent reservoir. Human population is divided into S, E, I, R compartments; rodent population into S and I compartments. Includes rodent-to-human transmission (β1), human-to-human transmission (β2), rodent-to-rodent transmission (β3), vertical transmission in rodents (ρ), and a nonlinear treatment term aI/(1+bI) for infected humans. Model analyzed for positivity, boundedness, disease-free and endemic equilibria, basic reproduction number (R0), global and local stability, backward bifurcation using center manifold theory, and sensitivity analysis of parameters.

Deterministic ODE model extending previous Lassa fever model; includes human compartments Susceptible, Aware, Infected, Recovered and rodent compartments Susceptible, Infected; models reinfection (loss of immunity) and awareness-driven reduction in rodent-to-human contact; spillover from rodents to humans via β_HV; no direct human-to-human infection; parameters taken from literature, not fitted to data; numerical simulations performed in Python (verification with MATLAB); code not publicly available.

assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Heterogenity in transmission rates - between human groups
notes: Gender-specific deterministic compartmental model (human males and females, rodent reservoir) for Lassa virus transmission, includes rodent-to-human and sexual transmission.

assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Heterogenity in transmission rates - between human groups
notes: Optimal control extension of the gender-specific model, includes four time-dependent controls targeting rodent-to-human transmission, detection/treatment, and rodent population control.

transmission_route: Vector/Animal to human;Human to human (direct contact)
assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Latent period is same as incubation period;Other
notes: Fractional-order SEIR-SEI compartmental model for Lassa fever incorporating rodent reservoir and saturation incidence; analyzed via stability and numerical simulation using Adams-Bashforth predictor-corrector method.

Deterministic ODE model of a seasonally fluctuating wildlife host population with compartments S, Sv, Ip, V, P, incorporating pulse vaccination and exploring frequency- and density-dependent transmission.
Stochastic version of the wildlife host model implemented via Gillespie algorithm as a Poisson process, simulating demographic and infection events and evaluating timing of pulse vaccination.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human
notes: Base deterministic compartmental transmission model for Lassa fever with human (susceptible, latent, infected, isolated, recovered with/without complications) and rodent (susceptible, latent, carrier) compartments, includes both human-to-human direct contact and rodent-to-human transmission.

transmission_route: Human to human (direct contact);Vector/Animal to human
notes: Deterministic optimal control version of the Lassa fever transmission model, extending the base model with time-dependent control variables u1 (treatment) and u2 (isolation) solved using Pontryagin's Maximum Principle and numerical simulation.

Deterministic compartmental ODE model with male/female susceptible and infected compartments, dormant and active vector compartments; includes sexual transmission (condom control) and vector-to-human transmission; assumes homogeneous mixing; includes vector control via pesticide; no data fitting.
Transmissible self-disseminating vaccine model with density-dependent transmission, four compartments (S, P, V, R), used for general simulations and rodent case study (Mastomys natalensis).

Transferable self-disseminating vaccine model with density-dependent transmission, five compartments (S, P, R, Pg, Rg), includes gel transfer via grooming, used for general simulations and rodent case study.
Transmissible self-disseminating vaccine model with frequency-dependent transmission, four compartments (S, P, V, R), used for the vampire bat (Desmodus rotundus) case study.
Transferable self-disseminating vaccine model with frequency-dependent transmission, five compartments (S, P, R, Pg, Rg), used for the vampire bat (Desmodus rotundus) case study.
Deterministic compartmental ODE model (system of equations for S, S_v, I_p, V, P) describing seasonal wildlife host dynamics, vaccination pulses, and frequency- or density-dependent transmission.
Stochastic implementation of the same compartmental model using Gillespie algorithm (Poisson processes) to simulate births, deaths, infection, vaccination events.

Model 1: Simple compartmental simulation of LASV infection and antibody dynamics in M. natalensis; constant viremia duration of 90 days for all ages; vertical transmission 5% (vertical and horizontal transmission sum 10%); horizontal transmission 95%; incidence of infection 5% per 30 days for age <240 days, 5% per 60 days for age >240 days; maternal antibodies present in 20% of newborns and lost within 120 days; parameters fitted to seroprevalence data.

Model 2: Extended compartmental simulation of LASV infection dynamics in M. natalensis with age-dependent viremia duration (300-600 days for newborns <30 days, 30 days for older); includes chronic infections and acute infections; vertical transmission 5% and horizontal transmission 95%; incidence of infection 5% per 30 days for age <240 days, 5% per 60 days for age >240 days; maternal antibodies 20% in newborns lost within 120 days; parameters fitted to seroprevalence data.

assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Heterogenity in transmission rates - over time;Age dependent susceptibility
notes: Model 1: Deterministic age-structured simulation of Lassa virus infection and antibody dynamics in a cohort of 20 Mastomys natalensis individuals using a 20x20 matrix in Excel. Assumes 5% vertical transmission, 95% horizontal transmission, fixed incidence (5% per month for age <240 days, 5% per 60 days for older), constant viremia duration (90 days), and maternal antibodies (20% prevalence, loss within 120 days). Parameters were empirically calibrated to serology and PCR data.

assumptions: Homogeneous mixing;Heterogenity in transmission rates - over time;Heterogenity in transmission rates - between groups;Age dependent susceptibility;Other
notes: Model 2: Deterministic age-structured simulation of Lassa virus infection and antibody dynamics in a cohort of 20 Mastomys natalensis individuals using a 20x20 matrix in Excel. Extends Model 1 by allowing chronic infections with long-term viremia (300-600 days) in newborns and acute infections with short-term viremia (30 days) in older animals. Assumes 5% vertical transmission, 95% horizontal transmission, age-dependent incidence (5% per 30 days for age <240 days, 5% per 60 days for older), maternal antibodies (20% prevalence, loss within 120 days). Parameters calibrated to match observed serology and PCR prevalence across age classes.
